Tensors are Tensor Fields

Invariant and isotropic tensors

Definition. Call a tensor TTT invariant under a given rotation RRR if all of its components remain identical after transformation by RRR:

Ti1i2...ip′=Tj1j2...jpRi1j1Ri2j2...Ripjp=Ti1i2...ip.T'_{i_1 i_2 ... i_p} = T_{j_1 j_2 ... j_p}R_{i_1 j_1} R_{i_2 j_2} ... R_{i_p j_p} = T_{i_1 i_2 ... i_p}.Ti1​i2​...ip​′​=Tj1​j2​...jp​​Ri1​j1​​Ri2​j2​​...Rip​jp​​=Ti1​i2​...ip​​.

Definition. If a tensor TTT is invariant under any rotation RRR, it is called isotropic.

All scalars are isotropic; no vector is isotropic because they have a fixed direction, and thus will always transform under rotation. In particular, we claim that

Proposition. There are only two nonzero isotropic rank p=1,2,p = 1, 2,p=1,2, or 333 tensors: a constant multiple of the totally symmetric rank 222 Kronecker delta δij\delta_{ij}δij​, and a constant multiple of the totally antisymmetric rank 333 Levi-Civita symbol.

Proof.

First we prove that both tensors are invariant. For the Kronecker delta, this follows from

δij′=δmnRimRjn=Rin(RT)nj=δij\delta'_{ij} = \delta_{mn} R_{im}R_{jn} = R_{in}(R^T)_{nj} = \delta_{ij}δij′​=δmn​Rim​Rjn​=Rin​(RT)nj​=δij​

as RRT=IRR^T = IRRT=I; for the Levi-Civita symbol this follows from

ϵijk′=ϵlmnRilRjmRkn=det⁡R ϵijk=ϵijk\epsilon_{ijk}' = \epsilon_{lmn}R_{il}R_{jm}R_{kn} = \det R\ \epsilon_{ijk} = \epsilon_{ijk}ϵijk′​=ϵlmn​Ril​Rjm​Rkn​=detR ϵijk​=ϵijk​

by definition of the determinant; note that if RRR is a reflection instead of a rotation ϵ\epsilonϵ is no longer invariant, as det⁡R=−1\det R = -1detR=−1.

To prove that the above two tensors are the only two possible invariant tensors, we consider ranks 1, 2 and 3 separately.

For rank 111 tensors, consider the matrix RRR of a rotation by π\piπ counterclockwise about the zzz-axis:

R=[−1000−10001]R = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}R=⎣⎡​−100​0−10​001​⎦⎤​

Suppose that TiT_iTi​ is a 111-tensor. For it to be isotropic, we must have

Ti′=RijTj=TiT_i' = R_{ij}T_j = T_iTi′​=Rij​Tj​=Ti​

Looking through the rows, this suggests

{−T1=T1−T2=T2T3=T3\begin{cases} -T_1 = T_1 \\ -T_2 = T_2 \\ T_3 = T_3 \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​−T1​=T1​−T2​=T2​T3​=T3​​

which gives T1=T2=0T_1 = T_2 = 0T1​=T2​=0. If −R-R−R is used instead of RRR, a similar argument is obtained for T3=0T_3 = 0T3​=0; thus, any isotropic tensor of rank 111 is a zero tensor.

For rank 222 tensors, considering

R=[010−100001]R = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}R=⎣⎡​0−10​100​001​⎦⎤​

yields

RikRjlTkl=TijR_{ik}R_{jl}T_{kl} = T_{ij}Rik​Rjl​Tkl​=Tij​

which across the individual rows yields

T13=R1kR3lTkl=R3lT2l=T23T_{13} = R_{1k}R_{3l}T_{kl} = R_{3l}T_{2l} = T_{23}T13​=R1k​R3l​Tkl​=R3l​T2l​=T23​

and

T23=R2kR3lTkl=−R3lT1l=−T13T_{23} = R_{2k}R_{3l}T_{kl} = -R_{3l}T_{1l} = -T_{13}T23​=R2k​R3l​Tkl​=−R3l​T1l​=−T13​

implying T13=T23=0T_{13} = T_{23} = 0T13​=T23​=0; the same argument can be made for all non-diagonal elements, which all vanish to 000.

For diagonal elements, e.g. T11T_{11}T11​, we havee

T11=R1kR1lTkl=R1lT2l=T22T_{11} = R_{1k}R_{1l}T_{kl} = R_{1l}T_{2l} = T_{22}T11​=R1k​R1l​Tkl​=R1l​T2l​=T22​

with similar arguments showing that all diagonal elements are equal.

Thus, all isotropic rank 222 tensors have equal diagonal elements and non-diagonal elements equalling zero; this is in the form αδij\alpha \delta_{ij}αδij​ for a constant α\alphaα.

For rank 333 tensors, considering both the above transformation matrices yields that Tijk=0T_{ijk} = 0Tijk​=0 if any two indices are equal and Tijk=−TjikT_{ijk} = -T_{jik}Tijk​=−Tjik​. This is in the form βϵijk\beta \epsilon_{ijk}βϵijk​.  □\ \square □

Rank 222 tensor decomposition

Theorem. Any rank 222 tensor (which is just a fancy name for a matrix) can be decomposed into a traceless rank 222 tensor and two isotropic tensors αδij\alpha \delta_{ij}αδij​ and ϵijkBk\epsilon_{ijk} B_{k}ϵijk​Bk​ for another tensor BBB.

Proof.

Begin with the symmetric/anti-symmetric decomposition of a rank 222 tensor TTT. For any TTT, we have

Tij=Tji+Tij2+Tij−Tji2T_{ij} = \frac{T_{ji} + T_{ij}}{2} + \frac{T_{ij} - T{ji}}{2}Tij​=2Tji​+Tij​​+2Tij​−Tji​

of which the first term is symmetric and the second is anti-symmetric; denote the first term SijS_{ij}Sij​ and the second AijA_{ij}Aij​. If the tensor SSS has trace QQQ, then the tensor S−Q3δijS - \frac{Q}{3}\delta_{ij}S−3Q​δij​ has trace zero ("traceless") due to the additive properties of trace; thus we have

Sij=Pij+Q3δijS_{ij} = P_{ij} + \frac{Q}{3}\delta_{ij}Sij​=Pij​+3Q​δij​

further decomposing SSS into a traceless tensor PPP and an isotropic tensor δij\delta_{ij}δij​. Similarly, we can decompose any antisymmetric tensor AijA_{ij}Aij​ of rank 222 into the product contraction

Aij=ϵijkBkA_{ij} = \epsilon_{ijk}B_{k}Aij​=ϵijk​Bk​

for some rank 111 tensor BBB, as Aji=ϵjikBk=−AijA_{ji} = \epsilon_{jik}B_{k} = - A_{ij}Aji​=ϵjik​Bk​=−Aij​. In total, this gives us

Tij=Pij+Q3δij+ϵijkBk.T_{ij} = P_{ij} + \frac{Q}{3}\delta_{ij} + \epsilon_{ijk}B_k.Tij​=Pij​+3Q​δij​+ϵijk​Bk​.

In particular, BkB_{k}Bk​ is 12ϵijkAij\frac{1}{2} \epsilon_{ijk}A_{ij}21​ϵijk​Aij​.

Tensor fields and their derivatives

Definition. A tensor field over R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 assigns a tensor Ti1...ikT_{i_1 ... i_k}Ti1​...ik​​ to every point x∈R3\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R^3}x∈R3; such a tensor field can be written T(x):R3→RmT(\mathbf{x}): \mathbb{R^3} \to \mathbb{R^m}T(x):R3→Rm, with mmm the number of components (not the rank) of the tensor.

Defining a (partial) derivative of a tensor field takes a bit of work. One possible interpretation is a component-by-component derivative: differentiating a tensor field just leaves us with the tensor containing the derivatives of all its components, much like differentiating a vector field. But with the tensor product, we can do something better.

Definition. Define the NNNth tensor-valued derivative of a rank-mmm tensor field TTT as the rank-m+nm+nm+n tensor XXX with components

Xi1...inj1...jm=∂∂xi1... ∂∂xinTj1...jmX_{i_1 ... i_n j_1 ... j_m} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i_1}} ...\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i_n}} T_{j_1 ... j_m}Xi1​...in​j1​...jm​​=∂xi1​​∂​... ∂xin​​∂​Tj1​...jm​​

where xi1,...,xinx_{i_1}, ..., x_{i_n}xi1​​,...,xin​​ are arbitrarily chosen variables in the domain of the tensor field.

Note that this is defined on a component-by-component basis: the components of this new tensor field are every possible nnnth-derivatives of the original tensor component.

We note, very importantly, that this is a tensor product - specifically, a tensor product between the original tensor and nnn different instances of the differential operator ∇\nabla∇, which makes a repeat appearance:

X=∇⊗∇⊗...⊗∇⊗TX = \nabla \otimes \nabla \otimes ... \otimes \nabla \otimes TX=∇⊗∇⊗...⊗∇⊗T

In order to prove that it indeed outputs a tensor, we need ∇\nabla∇ itself to be a tensor; why is this so?

Proposition. The differential operator ∇\nabla∇ is a tensor; it is invariant with respect to changes of basis.

Proof.

∇\nabla∇ is the vector operator given by

[∂∂x1∂∂x2⋮∂∂xn]\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_1} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x_2} \\ \vdots \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x_n} \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​∂x1​∂​∂x2​∂​⋮∂xn​∂​​⎦⎤​

awaiting a function to differentiate; suppose that we change basis via a matrix RRR to an alternate set of variables x1′,x2′,...,xn′x_1', x_2', ..., x_n'x1′​,x2′​,...,xn′​ such that, by the tensor transformation law,

xi′=Rijxj=Ri1x1+...+Rinxnx_i' = R_{ij}x_j = R_{i1}x_1 + ... + R_{in}x_nxi′​=Rij​xj​=Ri1​x1​+...+Rin​xn​

leading to

∂xi′∂xp=0+...+Rip+...+0=Rip,\frac{\partial x_i'}{\partial x_p} = 0 + ... + R_{ip} + ... + 0 = R_{ip},∂xp​∂xi′​​=0+...+Rip​+...+0=Rip​,

treating xjx_jxj​ as a variable to be differentiated. Similarly, we also have

xi=Rjixj′=R1ix1′+...+Rnixn′x_i = R_{ji}x_j' = R_{1i}x_1' + ... + R_{ni}x_n'xi​=Rji​xj′​=R1i​x1′​+...+Rni​xn′​

leading to

∂xi∂xq′=Rqi, ∂xq∂xi′=Riq.\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial x_q'} = R_{qi},\ \frac{\partial x_q}{\partial x_i'} = R_{iq}.∂xq′​∂xi​​=Rqi​, ∂xi′​∂xq​​=Riq​.

Thus by the chain rule,

(∇′)i=(∂∂xi)′=∂∂xi′=∂∂xq∂xq∂xi′=∂∂xqRiq=∇qRiq(\nabla')_i = (\frac{\partial}{\partial x_i})' = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i'} =\frac{\partial}{\partial x_q} \frac{\partial x_q}{\partial x_i'} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_q} R_{iq} = \nabla_q R_{iq}(∇′)i​=(∂xi​∂​)′=∂xi′​∂​=∂xq​∂​∂xi′​∂xq​​=∂xq​∂​Riq​=∇q​Riq​

which follows the tensor transformation law. Thus ∇\nabla∇ is a tensor.

As ∇\nabla∇ is a tensor, any rank-222 tensor product involving ∇\nabla∇ can be subject to our previous antisymmetric, symmetric and traceless tensor decomposition. For instance, we may have

T=F⊗∇, Tij=∂∂xjFiT = \mathbf{F} \otimes \nabla,\ T_{ij} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_j} F_iT=F⊗∇, Tij​=∂xj​∂​Fi​

for a vector field F\mathbf{F}F; it follows that this rank-222 tensor can be decomposed into the isotropic component

Tr T3δij=∂kFk3δij=(∇⋅F3)δij\frac{\text{Tr }T}{3}\delta_{ij} = \frac{\partial_k F_k}{3}\delta_{ij} = (\frac{\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}}{3}) \delta_{ij}3Tr T​δij​=3∂k​Fk​​δij​=(3∇⋅F​)δij​

the traceless, symmetric component

Sij−13∇⋅FS_{ij} - \frac{1}{3}\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}Sij​−31​∇⋅F

and the antisymmetric component

ϵijkBk=ϵijk(12ϵijk∇iFj)=−12ϵijk(∇×F).\epsilon_{ijk}B_k = \epsilon_{ijk}(\frac{1}{2}\epsilon_{ijk}\nabla_i F_j) = -\frac{1}{2} \epsilon_{ijk} (\nabla \times \mathbf{F}).ϵijk​Bk​=ϵijk​(21​ϵijk​∇i​Fj​)=−21​ϵijk​(∇×F).

Tensor integral theorems

Invariant integrals

Theorem. The invariance theorem. Suppose that TTT is a tensor defined by the integral

Tij...k=∫Vf(r)xixj...xk dVT_{ij...k} = \int_V f(r)x_i x_j ... x_k\ dVTij...k​=∫V​f(r)xi​xj​...xk​ dV

for some scalar function fff, position vector x\mathbf{x}x, and rotationally invariant region VVV (e.g. a sphere), where rrr is the spherical radius ∣x∣|\mathbf{x}|∣x∣; then TTT is isotropic.

Proof.

First, we prove that TTT is indeed a tensor. TTT transforms as follows:

Tij...k′=∫Vf(r)′xi′xj′...xk′ dV′\begin{aligned} T'_{ij...k} = \int_V f(r)' x_i' x_j' ... x_k'\ dV' \end{aligned}Tij...k′​=∫V​f(r)′xi′​xj′​...xk′​ dV′​

of which f(r)′f(r)'f(r)′ remains f(r)f(r)f(r) as it is a scalar (and also because radius is rotationally symmetric), the xix_ixi​s transform like tensors because they are represented by position vectors along the coordinate axes - i.e. xi′=Rilxlx_i' = R_{il}x_lxi′​=Ril​xl​ for some rotation matrix RRR - and dVdVdV does not transform, as a rotation does not change the magnitude of the volume component (det⁡R=1\det R = 1detR=1.) Substituting gives

Tij...k′=∫Vf(r)Ri′ixiRj′jxj...Rk′kxk dV=(Ri′iRj′j...Rk′k)Tij...kT'_{ij...k} = \int_V f(r)R_{i'i}x_i R_{j'j}x_j ... R_{k'k}x_k\ dV = (R_{i'i}R_{j'j}...R_{k'k})T_{ij...k}Tij...k′​=∫V​f(r)Ri′i​xi​Rj′j​xj​...Rk′k​xk​ dV=(Ri′i​Rj′j​...Rk′k​)Tij...k​

which obeys the tensor transformation law.

As such, we have

Tij...k′=∫Vf(r)xi′xj′...xk′ dV=Tij...kT'_{ij...k} = \int_V f(r)x_i' x_j' ... x_k'\ dV = T_{ij...k}Tij...k′​=∫V​f(r)xi′​xj′​...xk′​ dV=Tij...k​

because the integrand is a change of coordinates from x\mathbf{x}x to x′\mathbf{x}'x′, and does not affect the value of the integral itself (in particular, the Jacobian is det⁡R=1\det R = 1detR=1.). In other words, if the integrand is a tensor, it should transform like a tensor - and that means that the integrand is invariant in actual value (though not necessarily in representation) under a rotation.

Example. Find the value of a spherically symmetric integral over a single axis xix_ixi​ over a sphere VVV, given by the tensor

Ti=∫Vρ(r)xi dV.T_i = \int_V \rho(r) x_i\ dV.Ti​=∫V​ρ(r)xi​ dV.

Solution. As VVV is rotationally invariant, TiT_iTi​ is an isotropic tensor; but all isotropic tensors of rank 111 are zero tensors. Thus the integral is zero.

Example. Find the value of a spherically symmetric integral over two axes xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ over a sphere VVV, given by the 222-tensor

Tij=∫Vρ(r)xixj dV.T_{ij} = \int_V \rho(r) x_i x_j\ dV.Tij​=∫V​ρ(r)xi​xj​ dV.

Solution. By the above results, TijT_{ij}Tij​ must be an isotropic tensor of rank 222; the only tensor that fulfills these properties is a constant multiple of the Kronecker delta δij\delta_{ij}δij​. Thus we have

Tij=αδijT_{ij} = \alpha \delta_{ij}Tij​=αδij​

for some α∈R\alpha \in \mathbb{R}α∈R; as such, the trace of this tensor TiiT_{ii}Tii​ is given by

Tii=αδii=3α=∫Vρ(r)xixi dV=∫Vρ(r)r2 dVT_{ii} = \alpha\delta_{ii} = 3\alpha = \int_V\rho(r) x_i x_i\ dV = \int_V \rho(r)r^2\ dVTii​=αδii​=3α=∫V​ρ(r)xi​xi​ dV=∫V​ρ(r)r2 dV

where the right-hand integral evaluates to 4π∫0Rρ(r)r4 dr4\pi \int_0^R \rho(r) r^4\ dr4π∫0R​ρ(r)r4 dr. This leads us to

α=4π3∫0Rρ(r)r4 dr\alpha = \frac{4\pi}{3}\int_0^R \rho(r) r^4\ drα=34π​∫0R​ρ(r)r4 dr

and thus

Tij=(4π3∫0Rρ(r)r4 dr) δij.T_{ij} = (\frac{4\pi}{3}\int_0^R \rho(r) r^4\ dr)\ \delta_{ij}.Tij​=(34π​∫0R​ρ(r)r4 dr) δij​.

Tensor divergence theorem

Theorem. Tensor divergence theorem. Let Tij...k...l(x)T_{ij...k...l}(\mathbf{x})Tij...k...l​(x) be a tensor field; define the divergence of TTT with respect to some index kkk to be the sum

∇k⋅Tij...k...l(x)=∂∂xkTij...k...l(x)\nabla_k \cdot T_{ij...k...l}(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_k}T_{ij...k...l}(\mathbf{x})∇k​⋅Tij...k...l​(x)=∂xk​∂​Tij...k...l​(x)

taking kkk as the index of summation and all others as fixed. Then for a closed region VVV in R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 and its boundary SSS, we have

∫V∇k⋅Tij...k...l dV=∫STij...k...l nk dS\int_V \nabla_k \cdot T_{ij...k...l}\ dV = \int_S T_{ij...k...l}\ n_k\ dS∫V​∇k​⋅Tij...k...l​ dV=∫S​Tij...k...l​ nk​ dS

where n\mathbf{n}n is the normal vector to boundary SSS. (Note that the right-hand side is summed over kkk; it is in some respects analogous to F⋅n=Fknk\mathbf{F \cdot n} = F_k n_kF⋅n=Fk​nk​.)

Proof.

This is a consequence of the (regular) Divergence Theorem. Consider a vector field v\mathbf{v}v formed from a contraction of the tensor TTT with n−1n-1n−1 other constant vectors, i.e.

vk=Tij...k...laibj...cl\mathbf{v}_k = T_{ij...k...l} \mathbf{a}_i \mathbf{b}_j ... \mathbf{c}_lvk​=Tij...k...l​ai​bj​...cl​

with a,b,...,c\mathbf{a, b, ..., c}a,b,...,c being constant vectors. Applying the Divergence Theorem on vk\mathbf{v_k}vk​ gives

∫V∇⋅vk dV=∫Svk⋅dS=∫Svknk dS (divergence theorem)=aibj...cl∫VTij...k...l nk dS\begin{aligned} \int_V \nabla \cdot v_k\ dV &= \int_S v_k\cdot \mathbf{dS} = \int_S v_k n_k\ dS \text{ (divergence theorem)} \\ &= \mathbf{a_i b_j ... c_l}\int_V T_{ij...k...l}\ n_k\ dS \\ \end{aligned}∫V​∇⋅vk​ dV​=∫S​vk​⋅dS=∫S​vk​nk​ dS (divergence theorem)=ai​bj​...cl​∫V​Tij...k...l​ nk​ dS​

and directly expanding vkv_kvk​ into the above product gives

∫V∇⋅vk dV=aibj...cl∫V∇k⋅Tij...k...l dV\int_V \nabla \cdot v_k\ dV = \mathbf{a_i b_j ... c_l}\int_V \nabla_k \cdot T_{ij...k...l}\ dV∫V​∇⋅vk​ dV=ai​bj​...cl​∫V​∇k​⋅Tij...k...l​ dV

leading to

∫V∇k⋅Tij...k...l dV=∫STij...k...l nk dS\int_V \nabla_k \cdot T_{ij...k...l}\ dV = \int_S T_{ij...k...l}\ n_k\ dS∫V​∇k​⋅Tij...k...l​ dV=∫S​Tij...k...l​ nk​ dS

as a,b,...,c\mathbf{a, b, ..., c}a,b,...,c are all constant.
